comment.narrative:
Output Indicator 1: Enhanced effectiveness of crises management at national and regional level / awareness raising • Clear information system outreaching most vulnerable groups in place • At least 10 • At least 20. Output Indicator 2 Rapid community response: • at least 2 local response action plans developed Output Indicator 3: Electronic document management system - development of 3 interactive services electronic systems; - 100 mahallas/communities in highest need to be equipped with hardware and software and for the roll-out of the information management system ; - 5 mln women, youth and poor families expected to benefit from the services Output 3: Electronic document management system Baseline: 0 Indicators: Digital document management system development Web-platform development Targets: development of 3 interactive services electronic systems; 100 mahallas/communities in highest need to be equipped with hardware and software and for the roll-out of the information management system ; 5 mln women, youth and poor families expected to benefit from the services
Output 4:Enabling wider access to clean water for sanitation as COVID 19 preventive measure for women-led households and rural schools. Targets:10,000 woman-led households (or at least 40,000 people)

Output Indicator 1: Enhanced effectiveness of crises management at national and regional level / awareness raising
The RRF has coordinated a highly effective and innovative awareness-raising campaign across social media, mobile applications, flyers, radio and TV to limit infection in rural communities, and highlight resources for vulnerable communities in lockdown. The latter has included free online psychological counselling; a hotline to assist women experiencing domestic violence, and partnership with national pharmacies to distribute information materials. These efforts have also included reaching largely overlooked audiences. For the first time in Uzbekistan, sign-language translation was provided for TV psychological chat shows aimed at women, and for the government’s regular COVID-19 briefings. Similarly, Braille pamphlets on GBV were distributed through pharmacies, and homes for people with disabilities with government assistance. The UNDP AccLab has partnered with IT company DataSite, and the ICT Center of Namangan Region Municipality, to digitalize the process of receiving, processing, and monitoring assistance requests (primarily for food and medicine supplies) received through the Help Centers, which the government had created in each region in the wake of lockdown. A new online form allowed near real-time reporting, searchable metrics, and actionable insights, after quick training for the Help Center operators. From April 9 to May 21, more than 15,000 requests were processed via the new web-based platform. The AccLab also highlighted the environmental consequences and risks to public health surrounding proper disposal of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE). A partnership was formed with a supermarket chain and Makhsustrans waste collecting company to monitor and install safe disposal labelled containers for collection of PPE waste at 32 large grocery stores, and 150 waste collection stations, in Tashkent’s most populated neighborhoods, supplemented by public campaigns on social distancing, protecting people at risk such as elderly, and shifting to non-cash transactions.
Output Indicator 2: Rapid community response • # of local response action plans developed
The Japan-funded Aral Sea Programme recalibrated its activities in response to COVID-19, in conjunction with the Ministry of Health of Karakalpakstan (MOHK) for the procurement of PPE, and medical equipment, such as artificial lung ventilators and pulse-oximeters. UNDP also worked with the private sector to re-orient their production towards PPE and generate new jobs in soap and face mask production. For example, one Karakalpakstan business, Rano Sheber, produced 20,000 masks, 10,000 of which were then delivered to the MOHK and Community Health Volunteers (CHVs). CHVs, trained and coordinated through Telegram in 10 northern districts of Karakalpakstan, were part of a broader effort to utilize community response resources for recovery and information awareness.
Output Indicator 3: Electronic document management system Technical requirements for the e-doc system and web platform were approved by the ministry of mahalla and family support. The project has finaled the tender procedures for the procurement of the very software products. The server and computer hardware procurement ($25.000) process has been finished. 3 interactive services will be developed within the web platform project further in 2021.
Output Indicator 4: Enabling wider access to clean water for sanitation as COVID 19 preventive measure for women-led households and rural schools. All the required equipment procurement, installation and well drilling services have been completed . (providing access to clean water in Karakalpakstan) Further implementation follow up is planned in 2021
